metadata.title: Effective cyanosilylation of aldehydes with copper(II)-based polymeric catalysts

Centro de Química Estrutural Instituto Superior Técnico Universidade de Lisboa Av. Rovisco Pais Lisbon 1049–001 Portugal Graphical abstract The new 1D copper(II) coordination polymers (CPs) [Cu(μ-L1)(H2O)]n (1, H2L1 =2-(2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclohexylidene)hydrazinyl)benzoic acid) and [Cu(μ-H2L2)(H2O)]n (2, H4L2 =(Z)-2-(2-(1,3-dioxo-1-(phenylamino)butan-2-ylidene)hydrazinyl)terephthalic acid) and the known zwitterionic 1D CP [Cu2(H2O)2(μ-H2L3)(μ-L3)]n (3, H3L3 =2-(2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclo-hexylidene)hydrazinyl)terephthalic acid) were synthesized and tested as homogeneous catalysts for cyanosilylation of a variety of aldehydes to the corresponding cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ethers. Among these polymeric catalysts, 3, with a zwitterionic charater, is the most effective one, giving 86–99% yield of the ethers upon reaction of aliphatic and aromatic aldehydes with trimethylsilyl cyanide in methanol at room temperature in 4h. Non-covalent interactions (cation-π and tetrel bondings) involving the aldehyde substrate are proposed to assist the cyanosilylation reaction. Keywords CuII coordination polymers Zwitterionic complexes Non-covalent interactions Arylhydrazone linker Homogeneous catalysis Cyanosilylation of aldehydes 1 Introduction Coordination polymers (CPs) are very promising polymeric materials due to the possibility of combining various inorganic (i.e., metal ions) and organic components in systems of different dimensionalities and formally in infinite sequences [1]. They have already found their way to many applications, such as, effective and selective sorption of gases and components of solutions, catalysis, etc. [1,2]. However, the search for new and more effective materials continues, and new CPs and applications have been emerging [1–5]. We have found that arylhydrazones of active methylene compounds (AHAMC) [6–8], including those with barbiturate functionalities [9,10], can be effectively applied to create a variety of inorganic polymeric structures of different topologies and chemical organizations. They can act as effective catalysts in a number of oxidation [11–13] and/or CC coupling reactions [7,14], and in this work we expand the scope of possible catalytic applications of AHAMC-based CPs towards cyanosilylation reaction. Cyanosilylation of carbonyl compounds (Scheme 1 ) is one of the fundamental CC bond forming reactions in organic chemistry, while the obtained cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ethers can be used as key intermediates in the syntheses of such valuable compounds as β-amino alcohols, α-hydroxy aldehydes, α-hydroxy acids, etc. [15,16]. Several synthetic cyanosilylation procedures have been reported by using HCN and its salts, acyl cyanides, alkyl cyanoformates and trialkylsilyl cyanides as cyanide sources [17–35]. Trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN) is among the most useful cyanating reagents for the nucleophilic addition to carbonyl compounds, since it is easy to handle, possesses low dissociation energy of SiC bond, and provides a high atom economy without side reactions [36–41]. However, to improve yields and/or enantioselectivity of the cyanosilylation reactions, a variety of catalysts have been used. Among those are Lewis acids [42–44], Lewis bases [45–47], organic-inorganic salts [35,48–51], N-heterocyclic carbenes [33,52], amino-thiourea [53,54], V-, Mn-, Al-, and Ti-salen complexes [55–58], nonionic bases [59,60], oxazaborolidinium ion [61,62], chiral Ti-α,α,α,α-1,3-dioxolane-tetraaryl-4,5-dimethanols [63,64], Ti, Al-phosphine oxide bifunctional catalysts with carbohydrate or binaphthol scaffolds [65–67], Ti, Al-N-oxide bifunctional catalysts with proline, pyrrolidine and 1,2-diamino ligands [68–70], metal organic frameworks [71–73], etc. In spite of the extensive development, most of the listed protocols provide rather modest yields, require prolonged reaction times, harmful solvents and laborious separation procedures, among other drawbacks. Hence, a mild, efficient and environmentally friendly protocol for cyanosilylation of carbonyl compounds with TMSCN is still highly desirable. Cu-catalyzed cyanosilylation reactions have recently received much attention [74,75], mainly due to low price and moderate toxicity of the catalysts in combination with their high activity. However, the copper-based catalytic systems still can be improved in terms of their activity and sustainability. For instance, reaction times to reach significant yields are still long, while their shortening by application of elevated temperatures of microwave irradiation leads to the destruction of the cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ethers [76]. To improve the catalytic outcome, we decided to prepare new Cu CP catalysts, composed of Cu(II) ions combined with COOH functionalized AHAMC linkers, a type of system which had not yet been applied to that reaction. Thus, in this work we combine the abovementioned approaches towards the following aims: i) synthesis of a new AHAMC linker bearing a COOH group, (Z)-2-(2-(1,3-dioxo-1-(phenylamino)butan-2-ylidene)hydrazinyl)terephthalic acid (H4L2), and its use, along with the known 2-(2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclohexylidene)hydrazinyl)benzoic acid (H2L1) [77] and 2-(2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclo-hexylidene)hydrazinyl)terephthalic acid (H3L3) [78] AHAMC linkers, for the preparation of new 1D CuII-CPs; ii) application of the obtained polymers as homogeneous catalysts for the cyanosilylation reaction of aliphatic and aromatic aldehydes with TMSCN. A high catalytic activity is shown mainly by one of the Cu-CP, with a zwitterionic character, which is proposed to be promoted by non-covalent interactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and instrumentation All the chemicals were obtained from commercial sources (Aldrich) and used as received. The 1D CP [Cu2(H2O)2(μ-H2L3)(μ-L3)]n (3) was synthesized according to the reported procedure [78]. Solubility of 3 in MeOH, CH2Cl2 and THF:≥16.32, 3.67 and 2.89mmol/L, respectively. Infrared spectra (4000–400cm−1) were recorded on a Vertex 70 (Bruker) instrument in KBr pellets. Carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen elemental analyses were done using a “2400 CHN Elemental Analyzer” by Perkin Elmer. The 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Bruker Avance II+300 (UltraShield™ Magnet) spectrometer operating at 300.130 and 75.468MHz for proton and carbon-13, respectively. The chemical shifts are reported in ppm using tetramethylsilane as the internal reference. Electrospray mass spectra (ESI–MS) were run with an ion-trap instrument (Varian 500-MS LC Ion Trap Mass Spectrometer) equipped with an electrospray ion source. For electrospray ionization, the drying gas and flow rate were optimized according to the particular sample with 35 p.s.i. nebulizer pressure. Scanning was performed from m/z 0 to 1100 in methanol solution. The compounds were observed in the negative or positive mode (capillary voltage=80–105V). 2.2 Synthesis of H4L2 H4L2 was synthesized according to a well-established procedure applied to the preparation of H2L1 [77] and H3L3 [78] (Scheme 2 ), by azocoupling of 2,5-dicarboxybenzenediazonium chloride with acetoacetanilide in the presence of sodium hydroxide (see Electronic supplementary information). 2.3 Synthesis of [Cu(μ-L1)(H2O)]n (1) 0.1mmol (29mg) of H2L1 were dissolved in 20mL of methanol, then 2 drops of Et3N and 0.1mmol (23mg) of Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O2·5H2O were added. The mixture was stirred for 5min and left for slow evaporation. Greenish crystals of the product started to form after ca. 2 d at room temperature; they were filtered off and dried in air. Yield, 56% (based on Cu). Calcd. for C15H16CuN2O5 (Mr = 367.84):C 48.98, H 4.38, N 7.62; found C 49.01, H 4.27, N 7.63. Solubility in MeOH, CH2Cl2 and THF:≥13.21, 3.02 and 2.77mmol/L, respectively. MS (ESI, positive ion mode), m/z: 350.8 [Mr−H2O+H]+. IR (KBr): 3436 (s, br) ν(OH), 1686 and 1625 (s) ν(CO), 1609 (s) ν(CN)cm−1. 2.4 Synthesis of [Cu(μ-H2L2)(H2O)]n (2) 0.1mmol (37mg) of H4L2 were dissolved in 25mL of methanol, then 0.1mmol (20mg) of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O was added, and the system was stirred for 10min. After ca. 2 d at room temperature, greenish crystals precipitated, which were then filtered off and dried in air. Yield, 61% (based on Cu). Calcd. for C18H15CuN3O7 (Mr = 448.88):C 48.16, H 3.37, N 9.36; found C 48.24, H 3.42, N 9.27. Solubility in MeOH, CH2Cl2 and THF:≥15.15, 3.45 and 2.82mmol/L, respectively. MS (ESI, positive ion mode), m/z: 431.8 [Mr−H2O+H]+. IR (KBr): 3457 (s, br) ν(OH), 3031 and 2611 ν(NH), 1729 (s) ν(CO), 1594 ν(CN)cm−1. 2.5 Crystal structure determination X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 and 2 were collected using a Bruker SMART APEX-II CCD area detector equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo-K(radiation ((=0.71073Å) at 298(2) K. Absorption correction was applied by SADABS [79,80]. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares using Bruker's SHELXTL-97 [81]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The details of the crystallographic data, selected bond distances and angles for 1 and 2 are summarized in Tables S1 and S2 (Electronic supplementary information). Crystallographic data for the structural analysis has been deposited to the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC 1500744 for 1 and 1500745 for 2). Copy of this information can be obtained free of charge from The Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (Fax: +44 1223 336033; E mail: deposit@ccdc cam ac uk or www ccdc cam ac uk/data_request/cif 2.6 Catalytic activity studies In a typical cyanosilylation procedure, a CP catalyst (1, 2 or 3) (1–8mol%) was added to a mixture of aldehyde (0.4mmol) and TMSCN (0.6mmol) in solvent (2mL) at room temperature. The resulting solution was stirred at room temperature under air for a certain time. After evaporation of the solvent, the residue was diluted with 3mL water and extracted with diethyl ether (3×10mL). After removal of diethyl ether under vacuum, the extract was taken for analysis by 1H NMR spectroscopy in CDCl3, to evaluate the yield of the cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ethers [39,41,74]. the adequacy of the procedure was confirmed by blank 1H NMR analyses with 1,2-dimethoxyethane as an internal reference. The internal standard method proved that no side products were formed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of H4L2, 1 and 2 The synthesis and characterization of the linkers H2L1 [77] and H3L3 [78] and the CP 3 (Scheme 2) [78] were reported earlier by some of us, and hence will not be discussed here in detail. The new compound H4L2 was synthesized via azocoupling reaction between 2,5-dicarboxybenzene-diazonium chloride and acetoacetanilide in a sodium hydroxide water-ethanol solution, and characterized by IR, ESI–MS, NMR spectroscopies and elemental analysis. H4L2 exists in the Z-hydrazone form: in 1H NMR spectrum, the hydrazone N−NH− and the amide proton signals are observed at δ 14.79 and 11.04, respectively. The IR spectrum shows ν(OH), ν(NH)hydrazone and ν(NH)amide vibrations at 3457, 2928 and 2864cm−1, respectively, while ν(CO) and ν(CN) are observed at 1678 and 1597cm−1, correspondingly, supporting the Z-configuration of the hydrazone (Scheme 2). Elemental analysis and ESI–MS in methanol (peak at m/z 370.2 [Mr +H]+) also support the provided formulation of H4L2. The new 1D copper(II) CPs [Cu(μ-L1)(H2O)]n (1) and [Cu(μ-H2L2)(H2O)]n (2) (Scheme 2) were obtained by refluxing a methanol solution of copper(II) nitrate with H2L1 in the presence of Et3N or copper(II) acetate with H4L2, respectively. Green crystals suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained after 2 d. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 (experimental section) contain all the characteristic bands of the corresponding anionic ligand (L1)2− or (H2L2)2− in the hydrazone form, viz., 3436, 1686, 1625 and 1609 for 1 and 3457, 3031, 2611, 1729 and 1594cm−1 for 2. Elemental analyses and X-ray crystallography (see below) are also in agreement with the proposed formulations. In compounds 1 and 2 the (L1)2− or (H2L2)2− ligand binds the metal through one Oketone, one Nhydrazone and one Ocarboxylate atom, the coordination sphere of Cu(II) being accomplished with one water molecule (apical position), thus giving rise to a distorted square pyramidal metal environment (Fig. 1 ). In compound 2, the carbonyl group acts as Hbond acceptor towards the amide group leading to a strong intramolecular hydrogen bonding with N(3)⋯O(5) distance of 2.637(5)Å. Both compounds present multiple intermolecular (also intramolecular in the case of 2) hydrogen bond interactions that lead to 3D supramolecular networks (Fig. S1). 3.2 Catalytic activity of 1−3 in cyanosilylation reaction Initially, benzaldehyde was chosen as a test substrate to determine the best conditions for the aldehyde cyanosilylation with trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN) to afford the corresponding cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ether (Scheme 1). Since the yield of the cyanosilylation reaction is generally dependent upon the nature of the solvent [15–41], it was conducted in different solvents, such as 1,2-dichloromethane, THF and methanol, by checking Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O, H2L1, H4L2, H3L3, 1, 2 and 3 as homogeneous catalysts under similar reaction conditions (Table 1 ). The non-catalytic reactions of benzaldehyde with TMSCN, under solvent-free condition or in the presence of solvents, produce the cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ether, i.e. 2-phenyl-2-((trimethylsilyl)oxy)acetonitrile, in low yields (13–45%) (entries 1–6 in Table 1) with long reaction times (until 6days). Similarly, rather low yields (15–24%) are achieved in CH2Cl2 or THF solvents in the presence of a Cu catalyst or of the free AHAMC ligand (Table 1, entries 8–13 and 17–22). However, the use of methanol as a solvent greatly enhances the product yield in the presence of 1–3 (78–95%, entries 23–25, Table 1), whereas Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O, H2L1, H4L2 or H3L3 building blocks by themselves show much lower activities in this solvent (entries 7, 14–16 in Table 1). The higher catalytic activity of 3 (entry 25), compared to those of 1 and 2 (entries 23 and 24), can eventually be associated to the zwitterionic character of this compound, where the hydrazonium group can play a role in the stabilization of intermediate species and in the activation of the CO group of benzaldehyde (see below the discussion of the proposed mechanism). After the screening tests, 3 and methanol were chosen as catalyst and solvent, respectively, for the following studies. On the next stage of the study we optimized the reaction time and temperature, as well as the catalyst amount (Table 2 ). The increase of reaction time within 1–16h led to higher yields (entries 1–7) until 4h beyond which no appreciable yield increase occurs. The increase of the catalyst amount up to 5mol% loading resulted in an yield improvement (entries 8–13, Table 2) and thus this amount was applied for the further studies. The temperature above 25°C had only a small effect on the yield (entries 11, 14–17) and hence room temperature was typically used. Therefore, based on the above observations, the reaction conditions of entry 11 were chosen for the further cyanosilylation tests. To investigate the scope of the catalyst, we studied the influence of different substituents at benzaldehyde and of different alkyl chains at aliphatic aldehydes (Table 3 ). In all the cases, the corresponding cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ether product was obtained in a good yield ranging from 86 to 99% (Table 3). Aliphatic aldehydes displayed better results than benzaldehyde, with good yields (up to 99.3%, entries 1–3, Table 3) which appear to decrease with the increase of the length of the hydrocarbon chain. Aromatic aldehydes bearing electron-withdrawing groups (bromo, chloro or nitro) exhibit higher reactivities (Table 3, entries 7–9) as compared to those having electron-donating substituents (methoxy or methyl) (entries 4 and 5), resulting from an increase of the substrate electrophilicity in the former case (see below the proposed mechanism). In comparison with other known catalytic systems for the cyanosilylation of aldehydes with TMSCN [75,82–86], the CPs studied herein (especially catalyst 3) perform much better in terms of higher product yield in a shorter time (98% in 4h at room temperature) than most of the other metal-based homogeneous catalysts (Table S3) [37–41]. In most of those systems, longer reaction times and less convenient temperatures are required, while yields are generally lower. The overall mechanism for the cyanosilylation reaction of benzaldehyde with TMSCN in the presence of any of our Cu catalysts (e.g., 3, Scheme 3 ) is expected to be similar to that proposed for related catalytic systems [36,38,39,41,74,87], involving activation of the aldehyde upon coordination to nucleophilic attack by TMSCN. In our particular case, it can occur upon substitution of the labile coordinated water molecule for aldehyde to form an intermediate I (observed by ESI–MS at the positive ion mode in methanol, Fig. S4) (step I in Scheme 3). Its formation can be assisted by hydrazonium-phenyl (cation-π) interaction leading to an increased electrophilicity of the aldehyde carbonyl group. Subsequently, reaction of I with TMSCN can produce an intermediate II (also supported by ESI–MS analysis at the positive ion mode in methanol, Fig. S5) (step II in Scheme 3), stabilized by the above cation-π interaction and also by a tetrel (Si···O) bonding [88,89]. This non-covalent bond can promote the nucleophilic attack of the cyanide group to the aldehyde carbonyl moiety and the trimethylsilylation reaction to form the cyanohydrine trimethylsilyl ether. Replacement of this product by water (step III in Scheme 3) completes the catalytic cycle. Both non-covalent cation-π and tetrel bondings thus play a driving role and the former, which only occurs in the zwitterionic 3 compound, can account for the higher catalytic activity of this CP. 4 Conclusions Two new and one previously reported 1D copper(II) coordination polymers bearing carboxylic-functionalized arylhydrazones of β-diketones have been synthesized, characterized and applied for the cyanosilylation of aldehydes with trimethylsilyl cyanide. Among them, [Cu2(H2O)2(μ-H2L3)(μ-L3)]n (3) (H3L3 =2-(2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclohexylidene)hydrazinyl)terephthalic acid) is the most active one, providing cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ethers in high yields (86–99%) at room temperature in 4h. Electron-withdrawing substituents within the aromatic aldehydes promote the reaction yield, while an opposite effect is observed with the increase of the size of the alkyl group in the aliphatic substrates. The cyanosilylation reaction is proposed to be assisted by non-covalent interactions of the types of cation-π (hydrazonium-phenyl) and tetrel (Si⋯O) bondings involving the aldehyde. Compared to other related homogeneous catalytic systems, attractive features of those studied herein include the ease of preparation, and the short reaction times in cheap and convenient methanol media at room temperature. The proposed possible promoting role of non-covalent interactions deserves to be further explored. coredata.dc:description: The new 1D copper(II) coordination polymers (CPs) [Cu(μ-L1)(H2O)]n (1, H2L1 =2-(2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclohexylidene)hydrazinyl)benzoic acid) and [Cu(μ-H2L2)(H2O)]n (2, H4L2 =(Z)-2-(2-(1,3-dioxo-1-(phenylamino)butan-2-ylidene)hydrazinyl)terephthalic acid) and the known zwitterionic 1D CP [Cu2(H2O)2(μ-H2L3)(μ-L3)]n (3, H3L3 =2-(2-(4,4-dimethyl-2,6-dioxocyclo-hexylidene)hydrazinyl)terephthalic acid) were synthesized and tested as homogeneous catalysts for cyanosilylation of a variety of aldehydes to the corresponding cyanohydrin trimethylsilyl ethers. Among these polymeric catalysts, 3, with a zwitterionic charater, is the most effective one, giving 86–99% yield of the ethers upon reaction of aliphatic and aromatic aldehydes with trimethylsilyl cyanide in methanol at room temperature in 4h. Non-covalent interactions (cation-π and tetrel bondings) involving the aldehyde substrate are proposed to assist the cyanosilylation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Effective cyanosilylation of aldehydes with copper(II)-based polymeric catalysts
